top_ideas.description: Early Wittgenstein proposed that language functions by representing facts about the world through logical structures, or 'pictures.' A proposition is meaningful if it mirrors a possible state of affairs.

top_ideas.idea: Limits of Language = Limits of World
top_ideas.description: In the Tractatus, Wittgenstein argues that what can be said clearly can be said at all; everything else must be passed over in silence. Language defines the boundaries of what is thinkable and sayable.

Later Wittgenstein introduced the idea of language as a collection of diverse 'language games' embedded in specific forms of life. Meaning is determined by use, not abstract correspondence to reality.
Words derive their meaning from how they are used in practical contexts rather than from intrinsic definitions or reference to objects. This principle underpins Wittgenstein’s later philosophy.

Wittgenstein argued that a truly private language, understandable by only a single individual and referring to purely internal states, is incoherent because language is necessarily a public, rule-governed activity.

Wittgenstein questioned how following a rule is possible if no future application of it is logically entailed by a finite series of examples. Rule-following depends on communal practices and agreement.
Understanding a language requires familiarity with the social and cultural practices—'forms of life'—within which language has meaning. This concept ties language to shared human activities.
Many concepts (like 'game') lack a single essence but are united by overlapping similarities, or family resemblances. This challenges the traditional search for rigid definitions in philosophy.

Wittgenstein rejected grand philosophical theories in favor of therapeutic methods that clarify how language is misused in philosophical confusion. Philosophy should resolve confusion, not construct doctrines.
Wittgenstein conceived philosophy as a kind of therapy that dissolves confusions arising from misuses of language. Philosophical problems are illusions rooted in linguistic misunderstanding.
key_books: Remarks on the Foundations of Mathematics

top_ideas.description: In the Tractatus, Wittgenstein distinguished between what can be said (facts and logical propositions) and what can only be shown (ethics, aesthetics, metaphysics), asserting that the most important things lie beyond language.
